conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light; shape and size depend on object shape and light source position.
The length of the shadow is determined by the angle of the light rays relative to the object and the ground.
The light source is currently positioned above the objects, casting shadows behind them.
Moving the light source forward positions it more directly above the objects, reducing the angle of the light rays relative to the ground.
As the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift closer to the objects due to more perpendicular light rays.
The shadows will become shorter due to the reduced angle of the light rays, causing the shadows to contract.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to their respective objects.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will become shorter.
If the light source moves forward above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will shift closer to the objects and become shorter.
